title: About Me
text:
Hi! I am a PhD student in Linguistics at Brown University. I am part of the Cognitve and Psychological Sciences (CoPsy), and the Program in Linguistics, where I am advised by Uriel Cohen Priva.
Broadly, I am interested in how communicative, phonetic and learning pressures shape languages’ phonological systems, and I primarily use corpus data and computational modeling to address questions related this issue. My dissertation research focuses on quantifying and explaining the extent of nonlocal dependencies between segments across the world’s languages.
I have a parallel interest in deep learning interpretability, particularly as it relates to modeling the mapping from phonetic/acoustic to phonological representations. Some of my recent work focuses on whether phonological generalizations can be inferred from raw speech data and in particular whether information bottlenecks in deep learning architectures can yield human-like phonological generalizations.
Feel free to reach out with any questions!

title: Research & Projects
text:
Phonological Representations in Neural Networks

(How) are Neural Networks useful for Phonetics and phonology?
An advantage of neural networks for language modeling is their capacity to compress highly variable data in non-linear ways. They also make no assumptions about intermediate representations. However, even relatively simple architectures are black boxes, and their correspondence to linguistic phenomena is often ill-defined.


Contrasting the role of fully-connected and convolutional layers
A starting point for building interpretable and plausible models of phonological learning from raw speech is to consider how the architectural constraints of a model correspond to human-like computational constraints. Some of my work focuses on the division of labor between the fully-connected and convolutional layers, and how this can be leveraged to build plausible models.

title: Research & Projects
text: My dissertation work focuses on assessing whether the phonemic composition of lexicons is predicted by information-theoretic pressures like the need to communicate unambiguous signals. The composition of lexicons is both arbitrary but also guided by categorical and statistical restrictions on sound co-occurrence. I use tools like Bayesian regression modeling to answer: is the the distribution of sounds in the world’s lexicon predicted by usage-based or communicative pressures? Are non-local dependencies between sounds like vowel harmony facilitate the communicative utility of lexicons?

title: Research & Projects
text:
Phonetic Speaker Adaptation
My Master’s work focused on perceptual adaptation to novel accents, and what the statistical aspects of the input are that license certain kinds of adaptations. In particular, I found evidence that a high degree of speaker variability in exposure to a phonetic shift yields greater adaptation.

section: Representations of Speech Sounds in Humans and Neural Networks
text:
Representations of Speech Sounds in Humans and Neural Networks
I am also interested in how invariant representations emerge to begin with. One of the main advantages of neural networks for language modeling is their capacity to compress highly variable data in non-linear ways, yielding categorical or discrete-like units. They also make no assumptions about intermediate representations. However, even relatively simple architectures are black boxes, and their correspondence to linguistic phenomena is often ill-defined. I am interested in whether the generalizations characteristic of human phonetics nd phonological knowledge emerge from training on raw data.
